title: UV Bioreactor - Biosphere
summary: Led mechanical design and experimental execution for next-generation UV-sterilizable bioreactor systems under Department of Defense-aligned programs.
detail: Led mechanical design and experimental execution for next-generation UV-sterilizable bioreactor systems under Department of Defense-aligned programs.

sections.title: Role Scope
sections.body: At Biosphere (Arcology), I led mechanical design and experimental execution for next-generation UV-sterilizable bioreactor systems developed under Department of Defense-aligned programs. My role focused on translating system-level objectives into manufacturable hardware by defining architectures, owning critical component and subsystem design, and structuring validation strategies that ensured performance, sterility, and reliability at scale.

sections.title: Core Engineering Work
sections.body: I drove the design of core assemblies, including impeller, shaft, seal, and vessel interface systems, with emphasis on UV compatibility, aseptic operation, material durability, and long-term reliability. This included first-principles analysis, detailed CAD ownership, materials and surface engineering decisions, supplier coordination, and experimental frameworks that linked component behavior directly to process outcomes.

sections.title: Validation and Data Strategy
sections.body: I established testing throughput strategies, reliability targets, and data interpretation workflows so engineering decisions were grounded in measurable evidence rather than assumptions.

sections.title: Cross-Functional Program Execution
sections.body: Beyond component design, I coordinated execution across mechanical, process, and controls teams, ensuring engineering work aligned with program deliverables and Department of Defense performance expectations. I shaped experimental roadmaps, defined success criteria, and maintained technical coherence across parallel development efforts.

sections.title: Innovation and IP Contribution
sections.body: In parallel, I contributed to novel intellectual property by developing new hardware architectures and validating them through structured experimentation. This translated engineering insight into defensible innovations that supported both near-term program success and long-term technology differentiation.

title: Omni-Directional Treadmill
summary: Developed a VR-integrated omni-directional treadmill to improve rehabilitation outcomes with precise, multi-axis motion.
detail: Objective: Build a compact, multi-directional treadmill using omni wheels and control logic that keeps users centered at all times, in collaboration with Blue Goji.

sections.title: Project Objective
sections.body: Design a multi-directional treadmill using omni wheels so a user can move freely in any direction within a fixed space. The goal was to reduce the size of the existing prototype while adding a control system to keep the user centered. This was done with Blue Goji to improve physical and brain health.

sections.title: Principle
sections.body: A single-motor treadmill enables infinite motion in one direction. By combining two motors, motion can be produced in two axes. With the right motor speed variations, any 2D planar motion can be achieved.

sections.title: Approach
sections.body: We focused on downsizing without sacrificing efficiency or integrity. After multiple iterations over three months, we redesigned the drive system, reduced height by 44%, and increased safety factor using stress-concentrator analysis and topological optimization.

sections.title: Contribution
sections.body: I led the product design team, modified one drive system, and supported other sub-teams with FEA, rapid prototyping, proof-of-concept builds, and fabrication. I completed the full assembly in SOLIDWORKS, ran structural analysis on the platform, and contributed to fabrication, testing, and final assembly. The work culminated in a presentation at the Fung Institute Capstone Showcase.

sections.title: Note
sections.body: Specifics are withheld due to NDA restrictions.

title: Rumifico — Sharing Memories
summary: Collaborated with HP mentors to engineer a device that strengthens connections between parents and college-bound children.
detail: Human-centered design project with HP and a Google UX designer to reconnect parents and college students through shared memories.

sections.title: Overview
sections.body: Rumifico is a nostalgic, 21st‑century pager designed to help parents and kids who have moved out for college stay connected through shared memories.

sections.title: Collaboration
sections.body: We worked alongside HP and a Google UI/UX designer, applying human‑centered design to turn a meaningful connection gap into a tangible product concept.

sections.title: Recognition
sections.body: The project won the Best Overall Award at the UC Berkeley College of Engineering Jacobs Showcase 2022.

sections.title: Project Link
sections.body: https://www.behance.net/gallery/159089991/RUMIFICO-SHARING-MEMORIES/modules/897669701

title: Oxygen Concentrator
summary: Designed an oxygen concentrator using PSA technology with attention to functionality, space, and aesthetics through DFMA principles.
detail: Mission: Address the COVID-19 oxygen shortage in India by delivering a low-cost, compact PSA oxygen concentrator for small to medium hospitals (5–8 beds). The goal was a miniature, manufacturable alternative to full-scale PSA plants.

sections.title: Mission
sections.body: This project supported the Government of India’s effort to solve the medical-grade oxygen shortage during COVID-19. We targeted a low-cost, compact PSA concentrator (25 LPM) for small to mid-size hospitals, designed as a miniature counterpart to on-site PSA plants.

sections.title: Principle
sections.body: Pressure Swing Adsorption (PSA) uses synthetic zeolite sieves to adsorb nitrogen at high pressure, releasing oxygen. Two sieve beds alternate between pressurization and depressurization to maintain a continuous oxygen flow.

sections.title: Timeline of Work
sections.body: We began by modeling PSA valve timing and scaling from a 225 LPM plant to a 25 LPM concentrator. After simulations, we built a prototype to validate parameters while parallelizing enclosure and system layout design. Vendor manufacturing handled pressure vessels, allowing us to focus on assembly speed, cost, and serviceability.

sections.title: Design & Validation
sections.body: As one of two Product Design leads, I iterated the framework around constraints including size, weight, materials, aesthetics, electronics placement, mobility, airflow, and serviceability. Designs were reviewed with the engineering team and client and approved by the Technical Director.

sections.title: Key Contribution — Closure System
sections.body: To avoid welded thin sheet metal and exposed sharp edges, I developed a manufacturable closure system inspired by everyday mechanisms (CPU slide panels, angled screws in wood frames, and generator enclosures). This enabled safe, repeatable assembly for mass production.

sections.title: Key Contribution — Spring Plate Fix
sections.body: Testing revealed a small air gap at the top dish end plate that could grow over time as zeolite granules moved under cyclic pressure, increasing wear. After evaluating alternatives, I designed a compressed spring plate with seven springs to eliminate the gap as it formed. This prevented granule wear, improved efficiency, and was adopted in both projects.

sections.title: Impact
sections.body: The project was recognized by community leaders, including the Honorable central minister and regional hospitals, for its contribution during the crisis.

title: PSA Oxygen Plant
summary: Managed a 40+ member team to deliver a PSA oxygen plant, including non-destructive and pneumatic pressure vessel tests.
detail: Mission: Deliver large-scale hospitals an on-site PSA oxygen plant that provides continuous oxygen with minimal service needs and eliminates cylinder transport costs.

sections.title: Mission
sections.body: Design and deploy a one-time setup, on-site PSA oxygen generation plant for large hospitals. The system delivers continuous oxygen with minimal service requirements, removing reliance on cylinders and lowering cost by eliminating transportation.

sections.title: My Role
sections.body: I worked as a Production Manager alongside the oxygen concentrator project. Responsibilities included supply chain coordination, vendor management, post‑fabrication partnerships, workforce oversight, and quality assurance.

sections.title: Leadership
sections.body: I coordinated a team of 18+ contract workers (machinists, assemblers, welders), 4 engineers, and 4 support staff. I ran board-level project meetings, visited vendors, and maintained timelines to meet tight client deadlines.

sections.title: Hands‑On Engineering
sections.body: I produced 2D fabrication drawings, developed sheet metal parts for laser cutting, and designed supports for pressure tanks. I also gained experience with post‑production processes including sandblasting, painting, pressure vessel testing, dye‑penetration tests, and material treatment.

title: Make Kit
summary: Designed an educational maker service with scalable, reusable project kits that teach through hands-on building.
detail: Developed a maker kit program centered on the idea that 'Nothing teaches like a project.'

sections.title: Project Objective
sections.body: Develop an educational service for students, makers, and learners to gain new skills through hands‑on projects. The team researched, interviewed users, and generated concepts to create three scalable, reusable kits focused on usefulness and learning impact.

sections.title: Core Idea
sections.body: Nothing teaches like a project.

title: FSI Study of Arterial Model
summary: Created an FSI study using open-source tools to improve accessibility for medical image modeling and simulations.
detail: Research to promote open-source FSI tools for cardiovascular modeling, reducing cost and computational barriers in medical studies.

sections.title: Overview
sections.body: This research promoted open-source tools for fluid-structure interaction (FSI) studies to reduce medical costs in cardiovascular care. I led the academic study at MIT Manipal, comparing standard proprietary workflows with open-source alternatives using a coronary artery model.

sections.title: Tools
sections.body: We used SimVascular (SimTK), an open-source cardiovascular modeling and simulation suite developed at UC Berkeley and Stanford. Proprietary benchmarks used Mimics/CATIA for modeling and ANSYS Workbench for simulation prep.

sections.title: Method
sections.body: A coronary artery segment was modeled from MRI DICOM images with matched initial parameters across both workflows. We generated a 3D model, applied Delaunay tetrahedral meshing, and compared outcomes to evaluate the open-source pipeline’s effectiveness and improvement areas.

sections.title: Boundary Conditions
sections.body: Outlet conditions used an RCR Windkessel model, translating vascular behavior into an electrical analog (resistor, capacitor, current). Inlet waveforms and physiological values were sourced from literature.

sections.title: Roadblocks
sections.body: Two major issues were a lack of a system-wide units convention (CGS vs MKS) and limited Windows solver support. I wrote a Python scaling script for model.vtp files and configured an external solver to match SimVascular until platform support improved.

sections.title: Results
sections.body: Specific results are withheld as the work is being published. In comparison to standard tools, SimVascular provided comparable flow-parameter outputs with significantly lower computational cost and improved accessibility.

sections.title: Note
sections.body: This work is being published; detailed results are not disclosed.

title: Gravitational Effects on Boiling (ML)
summary: Studied gravity and Marangoni effects on boiling heat transfer using machine learning and genetic algorithms.
detail: Modeled water/2-propanol mixtures across varying gravitational conditions to identify optimized heat transfer behavior.

title: Solar PV Cell Optimization
summary: Built a neural network model to optimize PV cell organization for improved system performance.
detail: Validated the model with data and evaluated power output to identify best-performing cell combinations.

title: Boiler Performance Modeling
summary: Developed neural network models to predict boiler performance in solar thermal power plants.
detail: Trained models on real-world data for vertical tube boiling at 4.0 MPa and evaluated operating parameter impacts.

title: Turbine Blade Heat Transfer Analysis
summary: Analyzed heat transfer in turbine blades via modeling and experiments on an E423 airfoil.
detail: Investigated design optimization opportunities to improve thermal efficiency under varying operating conditions.

title: Engine Efficiency Through Thermal Design
summary: Designed a 6-cylinder radial pneumatic engine and improved efficiency through thermal-volume optimization.
detail: Modeled the engine in Autodesk Inventor and applied thermal mechanics to refine cylinder head geometry.
